column4: im having a strange behaviour. On a folder, I've got read access for group enabled and i am member of the group which the folder belongs to. but still when i try directory listing it gives me access denied error
try enabling the execute bit as well.
it worked by setting x bit ... why did this happen?
the execute bit allows directory search.
could you please tell me how to set execute bit automatically everytime a subdirectory is created?
you can set the mask to 027: "umask 027". new directories should have permissions "rwxr-x---"
might be easier just to change them all after the fact: "chmod -R g=rx <parent dir>"
is it possible to do it without changing the umask?
actually i wanna do it for a particular directory only
i'll have to do a chmod everytime a new subdir is created?
yes. consider writing a small script to do this if you find it tedious. or, as i mentioned earlier, you can use the recursive (-R) switch for chmod.
for certain reasons that isn't feasible for me
the sticky bit on a directory means that only owners of a file can delete that file, irrespective of the permission set on the parent directory.
chmod g+t doesn't have any affect. any idea?
